Award.AwardTitle: AF: Medium: Algorithmic Foundations for Phylogenetic Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
Phylogenies, or evolutionary histories, play a central role in biology as a framework within which to understand all of Life's diversity. In Charles Darwin's Origin of Species, the depiction of an evolutionary history of species took the shape of a tree. Ever since, trees have been the most commonly used structure to model evolutionary histories. However, while trees capture how, for example, one species splits into two that subsequently diversify and how genetic material is transmitted from ancestor to descendants, they fail to capture other evolutionary events. For example, some plant species arise due to hybridization between pairs of other species. In the microbial world, bacteria transmit genetic material horizontally by various means. In these cases, a tree gives an incomplete picture of the evolutionary history at best, and a very misleading one in the worst case. Indeed, a more appropriate model of evolutionary histories in these cases is a phylogenetic network, which extends the tree model by incorporating evolutionary events such as hybridization and horizontal gene transfer. Despite an increased research activity in the area of phylogenetic networks in recent years, their reconstruction and evaluation remain largely ad hoc processes and limited in their applicability to specific datasets.

To enable the development of methodologies for systematic reconstructing and evaluating phylogenetic networks, this project is aimed at developing (1) algorithms for evaluating the quality of phylogenetic networks using genomic data, and (2) algorithms for searching the phylogenetic network space to enable automatic inference of evolutionary histories.

The outcome of the proposed work will help significantly extend the applicability of phylogeny to groups of organisms for which trees are inappropriate, as well as to understand the phylogenetic network model, thus allowing for a more systematic development of methodologies for its accurate reconstruction. Further, the results will enable a more accurate reconstruction of the Tree of Life, help unravel microbial genome diversification, facilitate the reconstruction of hybridization scenarios in plants and other groups of organisms, and help understand the mechanisms by which microbes develop resistance to antibiotics.

The project provides outstanding opportunities for training graduate and undergraduate students in an interdisciplinary research area.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Phylogenetic trees, which form a fundamental model in evolutionary biology and, indeed, all of biology, are but a special case of the more general model of phylogenetic networks. A phylogenetic network takes the shape of a rooted, directed, acyclic graph, and models vertical and horizontal evolutionary processes. The overarching goal of this project is to develop new criteria for evaluating phylogenetic networks and new algorithmic techniques for inferring phylogenetic networks under these criteria. During the course of the project, several significant results were achieved. 

 

After deriving the probability mass function of gene trees on phylogenetic networks (Yu et al. 2012, PLoS Genetics 8(4): e1002660) and the parsimony criterion of minimizing deep coalescences on networks (Yu et al. 2013, Systematic Biology 62(5): 738-751), a full maximum likelihood framework was developed for inferring phylogenetic networks under the Multispecies Network Coalescent, which allows for incorporating incomplete lineage sorting into the framework, in addition to reticulation (Yu et al. 2014, PNAS 111(46): 16448-16453). Given the computational challenges that full likelihood computations on networks entail, inference based on pseudo-likelihood was devised (Yu and Nakhleh 2015, BMC Genomics 16(Suppl 10): S10) as well as new algorithmic techniques for speeding up likelihood computations on networks (Yu et al. 2013, BMC Bioinformatics 14(Suppl15): S6)). 

To account for model complexity in phylogenetic network inference, Bayesian methods were then derived, for phylogenetic network inference from gene trees (Wen et al. 2016, PLoS Genetics 12(5): e1006006), from bi-allelic markers (Zhu et al. 2018, PLoS Computational Biology 14(1): e1005932), and from sequence alignments (Wen and Nakhleh 2018, Systematic Biology 67(3): 439-457). To speed up computations from bi-allelic markers, a pseudo-likelihood based technique was developed (Zhu and Nakhleh 2018, Bioinformatics 34: i376-i385). 

All methods were implemented in the open-source software package PhyloNet and disseminated publicly, along with a publication that described its new features (Wen et al. 2018, Systematic Biology 67(4): 735-740). 

The project trained several graduate and undergraduate students, as well as post-doctoral fellows. The computational capabilities developed during the course of the project have already enabled new evolutionary analyses of genomic data and will continue to not only allow for more analyses but also for further developments of tools for phylogenetic network analysis. A book chapter that surveys the landscape in the field was published (Elworth et al. 2019, in Bioinformatics and Phylogenetics: Seminal Contributions of Bernard Moret, Springer).
